question: Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is associated with which of the following deformity ?
exp: TARDY ULNAR NERVE PALSY : may develop after: malunited fractures of the lateral humeral condyle in children, - displaced fractures of the medial humeral epicondyle, -dislocations of the elbow, - - contusions of the nerve. - In malunion of the lateral humeral condyle, cubitus va develops; in this deformity the ulnar nerve is gradually str and can become incompletely paralyzed. -also may develop in patients who have a shallow ulnar groov the posterior aspect of the medial humeral epicondyle,. - hypoplasia of the humeral trochlea, . - an inadequate fibrous arch that normally keeps the nerve in the groove, resulting in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the .nerve. ref : maheswari 9th ed

question: Muscles paralysed in Erb's paralysis are all except -
exp: Erb&; s palsy is due to injury to the C5 nerve root & rarely the C6 nerve root is injured . * Effects of injury - at shoulder : paralysis of deltoid , rhomboids , supra & infraspinatus & teres minor muscles . This results in loss of shoulder abduction & external rotation . - at elbow : biceps & brachialis muscles are paralyzed . This results in loss of flexion of elbow joint. - at forearm : supinator muscle paralyzed resulting in loss of supination of forearm - combined effect of injury is an arm hanging loose by the side of the trunk . The shoulder is internally rotated , the elbow is in extension , forearm is pronated & wrist is in flexion . This characteristic posture is popularly known as policeman or waiter &;s tip. - apa from this , there may sensory loss on outer aspects of the forearm both in front & back. REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer,4th edition,pg.no.350

question: Nerve damaged due to lunate dislocation is :
exp: In lunate dislocation, the lunate dislocates anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position. Lunate dislocation can lead to median nerve injury. Severe loss of wrist movements is inevitable. Avascular necrosis of the lunate is a common complication. same nerves are injured in carpel tunnel syndrome . REF:Maheswari 9th ed pg 116

question: Compression of a nerve within the carpal tunnel produces inability to -
exp: 9 tendon & 1 nerve pass through carpal tunnel . They are tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis & profundus in a common sheath , tendon of flexor pollicis longus in an independent sheath & the median nerve Median nerve - motor branches in hand are * flexor pollicis brevis : flexes metacarpophalangeal joint of thumb * opponens pollicis : opposes thumb towards the fingers *abductor pollicis brevis : abduction of thumb *first & second lumbricals : fex metacarpophalangeal joints , extend interphalangeal joints Sensory- palmar skin over the lateral three & half digits with their nail beds REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer, 4th edition ,pg.no.391
opc: Flex the distal phalanx of the thumb

question: A 54YR old male patient met with a road traffic accident and was brough to the ER ,he was unable to move his right arm .x ray shown below . which of the following nerve may be injured in this case ?
exp: AXILLARY NERVE SUPPLY : Posterior cord lower border of pectoralis minor Quadrilateral space Upper lateral cutaneous nerve of arm supplies skin over lower half of deltoid Nerve to deltoid Nerve to teres minor Injury results in loss of sensation over the lower half of the deltoid Weakness of the deltoid and the teres minor * Results from fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus and dislocation of the shoulder joint. * Impossible to test the integrity of the axillary nerve by testing the ability of deltoid to abduct the arm because of severe pain * The presence of a small area of lost or diminished sensation over the inferior half of deltoid enables the diagnosis of axillary nerve injury to be made. REF : MAHESWARI 9TH ED

question: Pen test is done for elliciting which nerve injury -
exp: Pen test is used to test abductor pollicis brevis * supply by median nerve * action - abduction of the thumb * pen test - the patient is asked to lay his hand flat on the table with palm facing the ceiling .A pen is held above the thumb & the patient is asked to touch the pen with tip of the thumb .It will not possible in case of median nerve injury . REF:Essential ohopedics ,Maheshwari, 5th edition ,pg.no.66

question: what happens in Klumpkes paralysis
exp: Klumpke&;s paralysis * site of injury - lower trunk of brachial plexus ( C8,T1) * cause of injury - undue abduction of the arm, as in clutching something with the hand after a fall from height , sometimes in bih injury . *Muscles paralysed- *intrinsic muscle of hand (T1), ulnar flexors of wrist & fingers (C8) *deformity - claw hand due to unopposed action of long flexors & extensors of the fingers . In claw hand there is hyperextension at metacarpophalageal joint & flexion at the interphalangeal joints. REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer, 4th edition ,pg.no.351

question: Ape thumb deformity is seen in involvement of -
exp: Ape thumb deformity : in this the thumb is in the same plane as the wrist .It occurs due to paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle in median nerve injury at the wrist & the unopposed action of extensor pollicis longus produces an ape like hand .The thenar eminence is wasted & flattened .The thumb is adducted & laterally rotated so that the first metacarpal lies in same plane other metacarpals. REF:Essential ohopedics ,Maheshwari ,5th edition , pg.no.64

question: A 56-years old female presents with nocturnal pain in the right thumb, index and middle fingers for the past 3 months. All of the provocative tests can be performed except -
exp: Finkelstein&;s test is for de Quervain&;s tenosynovitis - it is a condition characterised by pain & swelling over styloid process ,it results from inflammation of common sheath of abductor pollicis longus & extensor pollicis brevis tendons . on examination, the tenderness is localised to the radial styloid process .pain is aggravated by adducting the thumb across the palm & forcing detion against resistance( finkelstein&;s test) .There may be palpable thickening of the sheath. REF:essential ohopedics, 9th edition ,Maheshwari, pg.no.303

question: Meralgia paresthetica is due to involvement/injury of which of the following nerve ?
exp: Meralgia paresthetica is due to the involvement of lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh . *type - idiopathic , spontaneous , iatrogenic * clinical features - pain ,numbness, & paresthesia along the anterolateral aspect of thigh *Diagnostic test -if there is relief if pain after & paresthesia after injecting local anaesthetic * treatment : conservative - idiopathic : improve by removal of compressive agent ,NSAIDS & local steroid injection - iatrogenic : care should be exercised during pelvic surgery : surgery - neurolysis or transection of the nerves REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer,4th edition,pg.no.347

question: Phalen's test is used in which of the following condition ?
exp: Phalen&;s test / wrist flexion : done in carpal tunnel syndrome - the patient is asked to actively place the wrist in complete but unforced flexion . If tingling sensation& numbness is produced in the median nerve distribution of the hand within 60 sec, the test is positive .It is most sensitive provocative test. Has a specificity of 80%. REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer , 4th edition, pg.no 394

question: what is the Most common cause of tarsal tunnel syndrome ?
exp: Tarsal tunnel syndrome - the syndrome occurs due to compression of tibial nerve within the fibrous osseous tunnel under the flexor retinaculum of ankle joint .This is associated with pain & parasthesia in the sole of the foot often worse at night. ref : maheswari 9th ed

question: Median nerve lesion at the wrist causes all of the following except -
exp: Supply of median nerve in hand * motor- flexor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis , abductor pollicis brevis , first & second lumbricals Sensory - palmar skin over the lateral three & a half digits with their nail bed. Adductor pollicis muscle - supply deep branch of ulnar nerve , this muscle adducts the thumb. *it can tested by using Froment sign or book test In addition to it ulnar nerve supply in hand. * motor - abductor digiti minimi , flexor digiti minimize , opponens digiti minimi , adductor pollicis , all interossei & medial 2 lumbricals. REF:Essential ohopedics, Maheshwari, 9th edition ,pg.no. 68

question: Pointing index sign is seen in ____ nerve palsy -
exp: Pointing index sign or oschner&;s clasp test : in median nerve injury ( at a level proximal to elbow). When both hands are clasped together , index & middle finger ,fail to flex due to the loss of action of long finger flexors of index & middle fingers ( digitorum superficilais & lateral half of digitorum profundus ) . The other fingers can be flexed by the functioning medial side of the flexor digitorum profundus , supplied by the ulnar nerve. REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer, 4th edition pg.no. 338

question: Investigation of choice for entrapment neuropathy is-
exp: For diagnosis of nerve entrapment special investigation like electromyography & measurement of nerve conduction velocity may help to establish the diagnosis . USG & MRI are useful in excluding soft tissue mass Nerve compression syndrome Nerve compression syndrome or compression neuropathy, also known as entrapment neuropathy, is a medical condition caused by direct pressure on a single nerve . It is known colloquially as a trapped nerve, though this may also refer to nerve root compression . Symptoms Its symptoms include tingling ,numbness, and weakness&; . The symptoms affect just one paicular pa of the body, depending on which nerve is affected. nerve conduction studies help to confirm the diagnosis. In some cases, surgery may help to relieve the pressure on the nerve, but this does not always relive pain. Causes * A nerve may be compressed by prolonged or repeated external force, such as sitting with one&;s arm over the back of a chair , frequently resting one&;s elbows on a table or an ill-fitting cast or brace on the leg nerve) * Pa of the patient&;s own body can cause the compression, and the term entrapment neuropathy is used paicularly in this situation. The offending structure may be a well-defined lesion or a haematoma. Alternatively, there may be expansion of the tissues around a nerve in a space where there is little room for this to occur, as is often the case in to a specific condition such as aly, hypothyroidism or scleroderma and soriasis * Some conditions cause nerves to be paicularly susceptible to compression. These include , in which the blood supply to the nerves is already compromised the nerve more sensitive to minor injuries REF:MAHESWARI 9TH ED

question: Wasting of the intrinsic muscles of the hand can be expected to follow injury of the -
exp: Intrinsic muscle of the hand * muscles of thenar eminence ( abductor pollicis brevis,flexor pollicis brevis, opponents pollicis) - median nerve *adductor of thumb ( adductor pollicis) - deep branch of ulnar nerve * muscle on medial side of palm( palmaris brevis)- superficial branch of ulnar nerve * muscle of hypothenar eminence (abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponents digiti minimi)- deep branch of ulnar nerve * lumbricals - 1st& 2nd - median nerve; 3rd & 4th - ulnar nerve *palmar interossei & dorsal interossei - deep branch of ulnar nerve REF: MAHESWARI 9TH ED

question: Froment's sign is positive due to loss of -
exp: Froment sign is positive due to the loss of adduction of thumb in ulnar nerve palsy . The patient is asked to grasp a between thumb & index finger .Normally , a person will grasp the book firmly with the thumb extended , takjng full advantage of adductor pollicis & first dorsal interosseous muscles. If the ulnar nerve is injured , the adductor pollicis will be paralysed & patient will hold the book using the flexor pollicis longus ( supplied by median nerve ) in place of adductor . This produces flexion at interphalengeal joint of the thumb .This becomes more pronounced if the examiner tries to pull out the book while the patient tries to hold it .This sign is froment sign / book test REF:Essential ohopedics, Maheshwari , 5th edition, pg.no. 68
opa: Adduction of thumb due to ulnar nerve palsy
opb: Adduction of finger due to median nerve palsy
opc: Abduction of finger due to ulnar nerve palsy
opd: Extention of thumb due to radial nerve palsy

question: Tinel sign is used for depecting ?
exp: Tinel&;s sign is an impoant sign ,which helps in recording the rate of regeneration of nerve clinically . Procedure: gentle percussion is done along the course of injured nerve . Tingling sensation is experienced by the patient in the distribution of injured nerve rather than the area percussed , & the sensation should persist for several seconds following the stimulation .Positive tinel&;s sign indicate regenerating axonal sprouts have not obtained myelinization .Response fades as myelinization take place . Distal progression of response & rate of progression have been used by some to establish the prognosis ( rate of recovery should be 3cm / month) Presence of this sign is encouraging . Even a few regenerating sensory fibres can result in positive tinel&;s sign . REF:textbook of ohopedics, John ebenezer,4th edition, pg .no. 333
opa: To assess the severity of damage of nerve
opb: To classify the type of nerve injury
opc: To locate the site of nerve injury

question: Most sensitive test for carpal tunnel syndrome -
exp: *Phalen&;s test / wrist flexion : the patient is asked to actively place the wrist in complete but unforced flexion . If tingling & numbness are produced in median nerve distribution of the hand within 60 seconds , the test is positive . it is the most sensitive provocative test , has a specificity of 80%. *Tinel &;s sign - to record the rate of regeneration of nerve clinically . * Tourniquet test : a pneumatic BP cuff is applied proximal to elbow & inflated higher than the patient&;s systolic BP .The test is positive if there is parasthesia or numbness in region of median nerve distribution of the hand . Is less reliable & is specific in 65% cases. * median nerve percussion test : tap the median nerve at the wrist gently ,test is positive if there is tingling sensation .seen in 45% cases only * median nerve compression test : direct pressure over both wrist by examiner .first phase of test is time taken for symptoms to appear (15 sec- 2min) .the second phase is the time taken for symptoms to disappear after the release. REF:textbook of ohopedics, John Ebenezer, 4th edition , pg.no.394
